title: 112_hr44
content: The Act titled "Guam World War II Loyalty Recognition Act" recognizes the suffering and loyalty of the residents of Guam. The United States recognizes the suffering and loyalty of the residents of Guam during World War II, acknowledging the harm they endured under the occupation of Imperial Japanese military forces. Residents faced death, rape, forced labor, and internment, yet demonstrated steadfast loyalty to the United States despite the threats they faced. The United States acknowledges the suffering and loyalty of Guam residents during World War II, recognizing the harm they endured under Japanese occupation. The Secretary of the Treasury will make payments to compensable Guam victims for injuries suffered during World War II, with amounts ranging from $15,000 to $12,000 based on the type of injury. The Secretary of the Treasury will make payments to compensable Guam victims for injuries suffered during World War II, with amounts ranging from $15,000 to $12,000 based on the type of injury. Survivors of residents who died in war will receive $25,000 for distribution to eligible survivors, with specific payment distribution rules outlined. The payment distribution rules for compensable Guam victims are as follows: if the individual has a living spouse and children, half of the payment goes to the spouse and the other half to the child(ren). If there is no living spouse but there are children, all payment goes to the child(ren). If there are no living spouse or children but there are living parents, all payment goes to the parent(s). If there are no living spouse, child, or parent, no payment is made. The terms "compensable Guam decedent" and "compensable Guam victim" refer to individuals who were residents of Guam and either died or suffered during the attack and occupation of Guam by Japanese forces in World War II or during the liberation by US forces. The death of a compensable Guam decedent would have been compensable under the Guam Meritorious Claims Act of 1945. The Foreign Claims Settlement Commission will define severe personal injuries and personal injuries for compensation purposes related to acts such as rape, forced labor, disfigurement, and forced march during wartime. SEC. 4. ADJUDICATION. The Foreign Claims Settlement Commission has the authority to adjudicate claims and determine eligibility for payments under section 3. The chairman is responsible for creating necessary rules and regulations for the Commission, which must be published in the Federal Register. Claims must be submitted in a specific manner and form for the Commission to determine eligibility for payments. The Foreign Claims Settlement Commission requires claims to be filed within a specified period and provides public notice of the deadline through various media on Guam. Adjudicatory decisions on claims are made by majority vote, in writing, and must include reasons for the decision. The Foreign Claims Settlement Commission requires claims to be filed within a specified period and provides public notice of the deadline through various media on Guam. Adjudicatory decisions on claims are made by majority vote in writing, stating reasons for approval or denial, amount awarded, and any deductions. No interest is paid on awarded payments, and remuneration for representational services cannot exceed one percent of the total amount paid. After a claim is approved by the Foreign Claims Settlement Commission, any payment certified must not exceed the maximum permitted amount. Violators may face fines or imprisonment. Appeals of Commission decisions go back to the Commission for finality, with no further review by any court or agency. The Commission chairman certifies approved claims to the Secretary of the Treasury. The Foreign Claims Settlement Commission certifies approved claims to the Secretary of the Treasury for payment authorization under section 3. Claims accompanied by an affidavit attesting to all necessary facts establish prima facie eligibility for payment without further documentation, except as required by the Commission. Material facts must include a detailed description of the injury or circumstance supporting the claim and the amount sought. Acceptance of payment under section 3 for a claim related to a compensable Guam decedent or victim shall satisfy all related claims under the Guam Meritorious Claims Act of 1945 or this title. The Secretary of the Interior will establish a grants program to honor the loyalty of the people of Guam during World War II through research, educational, and media activities. Grants will be awarded for activities that memorialize the events surrounding the occupation of Guam, aiming to illuminate and interpret similar occupations during wars. Applicants must submit an application to be eligible for a grant. Authorization of appropriations is provided for this program. Authorization of appropriations is provided for Guam World War II claims payments and adjudication, with $100,000,000 authorized for the Foreign Claims Settlement Commission. Additionally, $5,000,000 is authorized for the Guam World War II grants program.
